body:
You need to have the right git tag applied AFAIK.
Or are you saying it started happening after this release?

I am not doing a GIT checkout, I am using the tar.gz you published

I dont know if this has happened before, 0.10.26 was my first RPM for your software

I think if you're not building from git, you need to specify the tag manually:
See: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/975
But, if you publish a tar.gz i thing it should work without any GIT, right?

It does, but you need to build it correctly. (Also, Github publishes the .tar.gz, we have no say in it. :)

`go run build.go -help`

Use the `-version` flag to tag it.
I added a note about this to https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/wiki/Building
We could solve this nicer though. Tagging as a build thing...

All solutions to this suck somewhat. Am I missing an awesome option?

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/wiki/WIP---Build-Strategies

git published source tarball always contains directory syncthing-_release_/, so if everything fails, build script can look for directory with such name in current path and extract version string from it - example in python

Actually, guessing from directory doesn't work. It works on my system if I download and build like that, but that's because I already have stuff in my GOPATH, but if you just download and try to build from a version-named directory you get this;

```
jb@syno:~/Downloads/syncthing-0.10.26 $ unset GOPATH
jb@syno:~/Downloads/syncthing-0.10.26 $ ./build.sh 
GOPATH is /
GOPATH=/Users/jb/Downloads/syncthing-0.10.26/Godeps/_workspace:/
go install -v -ldflags -w -X main.Version v0.10.26 -X main.BuildStamp 1426237403 -X main.BuildUser jb -X main.BuildHost syno -X main.BuildEnv default ./cmd/...
cmd/stcompdirs/main.go:28:2: cannot find package "github.com/syncthing/syncthing/internal/symlinks" in any of:
    /usr/local/go/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/internal/symlinks (from $GOROOT)
    /Users/jb/Downloads/syncthing-0.10.26/Godeps/_workspace/src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/internal/symlinks (from $GOPATH)
    /src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/internal/symlinks
...
```

So probably that bit should be reverted (to not give a false impression of that stuff working) and tagged source builds created on Jenkins. Go builds are annoying sometimes.

Question: if we build release tarballs (of source), is it worth letting them expand into `src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/...` so that a cd into that directory and `go run build.go` is guaranteed to work, or is that super annoying and unexpected?
That won't work as we'd have to change imports to use vendor imports.

No, that's fine, build.go wrangles the GOPATH to manage that. But it can't wrangle the GOPATH correctly unless the path to the source is right to start with.

Although, we may want to do changed-import vendoring in order to avoid having to wrangle GOPATH too much to start with...

http://build.syncthing.net/job/syncthing-release/1782/artifact/syncthing-source-v0.10.26.tar.gz

With RELEASE tag (but without the code that uses it, since it's v0.10.26).

Done, my RPMs for Centos6 and 7 are here:https://okay.com.mx/en/linux/rpm-repositories-for-centos-6-and-7.html  ony for 64 bits, I havent had the time to install a 32 bits machine, and cross compilation wont work.  Just type: yum install syncthing   after adding my repo

So from v0.10.27, there's be a file called RELEASE in the source tarball, which will be uploaded to to the Github releases page. Note that this is different from the Github auto generated tarballs at the bottom of the page. The build script will pick up this file and tag the binary correctly.
